G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and G.L. c. 186, § 14 further provides that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and G.L. c. 186, § 14 further provides that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” See, e.g., *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that G.L. c. 186, § 14 codified tenants’ common-law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that, as revised, it prohibits landlords from “directly or indirectly” interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. While the main holding concerns the level of landlord fault needed under § 14, the court’s description of the statute confirms that every tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and that § 14 provides the statutory quiet-enjoyment protection against interference.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. In 1973, the statute was rewritten and the requirement of intentional conduct was eliminated; landlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, and G.L. c. 186, § 14 further provides that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” See, e.g., *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997); *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 716–18 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment in the landlord‑tenant relationship and treats its breach as the basis for constructive eviction, which aligns with the first part of the proposition. However, Blackett is a common‑law quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction case and does not cite or interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it quote the statutory phrase about not directly or indirectly interfering with quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports the implied covenant aspect, but not the statutory language directly.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: "He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises."

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 and 19A.proposition: The Somerville District Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 19A, and G.L. c. 212, because the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 212.proposition: The Somerville District Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 and 19A, and G.L. c. 212, because the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and the claims arise under Massachusetts law.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the Premises are located in Somerville, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this judicial district.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 8.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 223, § 8 because the Premises are located in Somerville, Massachusetts, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred in this judicial district.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 717\u2.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act is not a mere omission in the abstract; by continuing to rent and maintain the upstairs apartment in a manner that allows serious and chronic noise disturbances to persist, after repeated actual notice, Defendant has indirectly but substantially interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and controlling precedent. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 717–19 (landlord liable for interference with quiet enjoyment where third‑party conduct is a “natural and probable consequence” of landlord’s actions or inactions); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284–86 (1994).

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act is not a mere omission in the abstract; by continuing to rent and maintain the upstairs apartment in a manner that allows serious and chronic noise disturbances to persist, after repeated actual notice, Defendant has indirectly but substantially interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and controlling precedent. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 717–19 (landlord liable for interference with quiet enjoyment where third‑party conduct is a “natural and probable consequence” of landlord’s actions or inactions); *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 284–86 (1994).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly applies Blackett’s ‘natural and probable consequence’ standard to a landlord’s omissions and holds that a landlord can ‘indirectly’ interfere with quiet enjoyment through failure to act after notice, where third‑party misconduct on common areas substantially impairs tenants’ use. While the facts concern drug activity in common areas rather than an upstairs neighbor’s noise, the principle is the same: a landlord’s continued operation and control of the premises, combined with inaction after repeated notice, can amount to an indirect but substantial interference under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Thus the case supports the proposition as a matter of legal doctrine, even though the specific disturbance type differs.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716 (1977). Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, after repeated actual notice of the problem and its seriousness, was willful or, at a minimum, in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s rights under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982); *Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.*, 439 Mass. 512, 515–18 (2003).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 and finds the landlord liable for failure to provide heat, but it expressly states that intent is not required and deliberately declines to reach whether the failure was intentional. The court imposes liability based on the natural and probable consequences of the landlord’s conduct, not on a finding of willful or reckless disregard after repeated notice. Thus, the case supports strict liability-style quiet enjoyment liability, not the specific proposition about willful or reckless conduct after repeated actual notice.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is control[ling].’… Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’… Our holding on the quiet enjoyment claim renders it unnecessary to consider the tenant’s additional claim that the failure to provide heat was intentional.”

Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512, 515–18 (2003)
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Defendant’s conduct, after repeated actual notice of the problem and its seriousness, was willful or, at a minimum, in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s rights under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 983–84 (1982); *Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.*, 439 Mass. 512, 515–18 (2003).
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.support_reasoning: The Fafard opinion is about whether counterclaims are procedurally allowed in commercial summary process actions under G.L. c. 239, § 8A; it does not involve G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor any discussion of willful or reckless disregard of a tenant’s statutory rights. The case’s analysis is limited to statutory interpretation of the summary process scheme and treatment of counterclaims, not landlord misconduct or mental state standards. Accordingly, it does not support the proposition regarding willful or reckless violations of c. 186, § 14.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.relevant_excerpt: “We transferred this case here on our own motion to decide whether a counterclaim may be filed in a commercial summary process action, particularly given the adoption of the rule of mutually dependant covenants in commercial leases… Because we agree with the trial judge’s determination that a counterclaim is not a proper procedural device in a commercial summary process action, we affirm the judgment… General Laws c. 239, § 8A, which creates a right to file counterclaims in summary process proceedings, states in pertinent part… Because we conclude that the summary process statute precludes counterclaims in commercial actions…”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. at 850\u20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord is liable where he “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” This statutory covenant supplements and reinforces the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in residential tenancies. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. at 850–52; *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord is liable where he “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” This statutory covenant supplements and reinforces the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment implied in residential tenancies. See *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. at 850–52; *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 102–06 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14, explaining that the statute makes a landlord liable when it “directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and explicitly links this statutory protection with the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion traces the common‑law background of “quiet enjoyment,” cites prior quiet‑enjoyment cases, and states that the Legislature, by using that term, intended to incorporate that body of law, thereby supplementing and expanding common‑law remedies. This aligns with the proposition that § 14 supplements and reinforces the common‑law covenant in residential tenancies.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing.… The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. at 718\u2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when the landlord’s actions or inactions, after notice, result in recurring conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises—even when the immediate source of the disturbance is a third party. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 718–19; *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. at 284–86.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. at 284–86
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 when the landlord’s actions or inactions, after notice, result in recurring conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises—even when the immediate source of the disturbance is a third party. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. at 718–19; *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. at 284–86.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102\u2013.proposition: A breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs when the interference is “serious” and “substantial,” and not merely a trifling annoyance or inconvenience. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–03; *Winchester v. O’Brien*, 266 Mass. 33, 36–37 (1929).

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: A breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment occurs when the interference is “serious” and “substantial,” and not merely a trifling annoyance or inconvenience. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–03; *Winchester v. O’Brien*, 266 Mass. 33, 36–37 (1929).
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The court expressly characterizes the landlord’s conduct as a “substantial and continued interference” with the tenant’s beneficial enjoyment, in contrast to earlier references to constructive eviction, showing that the threshold for breach involves serious, not trivial, interference. The opinion also distinguishes situations where only minimal interference exists and emphasizes that liability arises where the landlord’s acts “substantially impair the character and value of the leased premises.” This directly aligns with the formulation that a breach of quiet enjoyment requires serious and substantial interference, not mere annoyance or inconvenience.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … If a landlord authorizes acts to be done which cause substantial injury to the tenant in the peaceful enjoyment of the demised premises … the landlord is liable therefor. … It is evident from the facts found that there has been a substantial and continued interference with the plaintiff’s beneficial enjoyment of the leased premises and appurtenant rights by the acts done or authorized by the defendants…”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102\u2013.proposition: The level, frequency, and duration of the noise and disturbances have substantially impaired Plaintiff’s use of her home and sleep, and have caused health, emotional, and economic harm, constituting a serious interference with her tenancy under Massachusetts law. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–06; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 873–74 (1991) (emotional distress damages recoverable for breach of quiet enjoyment); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. at 850–52.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 873\u.proposition: The level, frequency, and duration of the noise and disturbances have substantially impaired Plaintiff’s use of her home and sleep, and have caused health, emotional, and economic harm, constituting a serious interference with her tenancy under Massachusetts law. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–06; *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855, 873–74 (1991) (emotional distress damages recoverable for breach of quiet enjoyment); *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. at 850–52.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 873\u.support_reasoning: Haddad concerns emotional distress damages under Massachusetts consumer protection law (G.L. c. 93A) and the landlord’s breach of warranty of habitability and quiet enjoyment-type conduct, but the passages at 873–74 focus on the measure of habitability damages and a dissent about multiplying emotional distress damages under c. 93A. The case does not address noise, sleep disturbance, or define what constitutes a “serious interference with tenancy” in the sense described in the proposition; that principle comes from Simon v. Solomon and similar cases, not from this section of Haddad. Thus, citing Haddad for substantial impairment of use of a home by noise and related harms is not accurate authority.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855, 873\u.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, in appropriate circumstances, tenants may recover multiple damages for the intentional infliction of emotional distress under c. 93A…. Gonzalez agreed to rent an apartment that complied with the State Sanitary Code, worth $375 per month, and she was entitled to damages that gave her the benefit of her bargain.”

Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. at 515–18
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to take reasonable steps to address the ongoing disturbances, despite repeated notice and an ongoing duty to maintain Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, was intentional, willful, or in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s statutory and contractual rights. See *Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.*, 439 Mass. at 515–18; *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at 983–84.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at 983–84
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at.proposition: Defendant’s failure and refusal to take reasonable steps to address the ongoing disturbances, despite repeated notice and an ongoing duty to maintain Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment, was intentional, willful, or in reckless disregard of Plaintiff’s statutory and contractual rights. See *Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.*, 439 Mass. at 515–18; *Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct. at 983–84.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 110\u2013.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is therefore entitled to statutory damages of at least $5,400, plus costs, because three months’ rent exceeds her claimed actual damages. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 110–11 (statutory minimum damages under § 14); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. at 872–75.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. at 872\u20.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Plaintiff is therefore entitled to statutory damages of at least $5,400, plus costs, because three months’ rent exceeds her claimed actual damages. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 110–11 (statutory minimum damages under § 14); *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. at 872–75.
